channel.title: NYT > Books > Book Review
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Books on Democracy Under Threat
item.description: It’s among the world’s oldest forms of government, but it’s increasingly under threat. These books consider the sources and effects of an alarming global trend.
item.dc:creator: Richard Stengel
item.category: How Civil Wars Start: And How to Stop Them (Book)
The Road to Unfreedom: Russia, Europe, America (Book)
Twilight of Democracy: The Seductive Lure of the Authoritarian State (Book)
How Fascism Works: The Politics of Us and Them (Book)
The Next Civil War: Dispatches From the American Future (Book)
The Great Experiment: Why Diverse Democracies Fall Apart and How They Can Endure (Book)

item.title: Adaptations of ‘Anne of Green Gables’ Are Proliferating
item.description: Suddenly, remakes and adaptations of L.M. Montgomery’s “Anne of Green Gables” series are proliferating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hong
item.category: Anne: An Adaptation of 'Anne of Green Gables' (Sort Of) (Book)
item.media:credit: M. A. and W. A. J. Claus

item.title: Book Review: ‘Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party,’ by Stephen Shames and Ericka Huggins
item.description: From schools to free food and health care, the group’s majority female membership carried out life-sustaining, grass-roots programs that went far beyond politics.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.category: Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party (Book)

item.title: Sizzling, Sparking, White-Hot Romance Novels
item.description: Nothing is more satisfying than the emotional combustion of characters who were meant to be together.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Waite

item.title: Bono By the Book Interview
item.description: “I got a copy of Edna O’ Brien’s ‘The Country Girls’ growing up, which hurried my puberty to a place where I thought differently about girls and women,” says the singer and frontman for U2, whose new memoir is “Surrender.” “I still do.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘Shuna’s Journey,’ by Hayao Miyazaki
item.description: First published in Japan in 1983, this picture book from the fabled animator is eerie, enchanting and surpassingly strange.
item.dc:creator: Susan Napier

item.title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: The Third Reconstruction: America's Struggle for Racial Justice in the Twenty-First Century (Book)
Blood & Ink: The Scandalous Jazz Age Double Murder That Hooked America on True Crime (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Art Is Life,’ by Jerry Saltz
item.description: “Art Is Life” collects the art critic’s essays, reviews, interviews and more from the past two decades.
item.dc:creator: Zoë Lescaze
item.category: Art Is Life: Icons and Iconoclasts, Visionaries and Vigilantes, and Flashes of Hope in the Night (Book)
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: “Gilded Mountain,” Kate Manning
item.description: In “Gilded Mountain,” Kate Manning explores the bedrock of the labor movement through the experience of one family.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan

item.title: The Haunted Past
item.description: What ghost stories of the formerly enslaved tell us about their lives.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Wilson

item.title: Book Review: ‘A Spectre, Haunting: On the Communist Manifesto,’ by China Miéville
item.description: In “A Spectre, Haunting,” the British fantasy writer and political activist China Miéville makes the case for why Marx and Engels’s famous pamphlet remains vital today.
item.dc:creator: Cory Doctorow

item.title: Review: ‘The Singularities,’ by John Banville
item.description: “The Singularities” is an ambitiously referential work that confronts some of humanity’s greatest challenges.
item.dc:creator: Leo Robson

item.title: Books That Teach Children About War Without Frightening Them
item.description: Four new picture books tackle the subject in sensitive, reassuring ways.
item.dc:creator: Eugene Yelchin
item.category: The Tower of Life: How Yaffa Eliach Rebuilt Her Town in Stories and Photographs (Book)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Book Review: ‘Martha Graham: When Dance Became Modern,’ by Neil Baldwin
item.description: The most revealing statements in a new biography come from the dancers who gave their lives and bodies to her experiments.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.category: Martha Graham: When Dance Became Modern: A Life (Book)
item.media:description: Martha Graham in “Clytemnestra,” 1960. Agnes de Mille said Graham was “among the last of the sacrificial females.”

item.title: Steps in the Left Direction
item.description: Playbooks for political change from Robert Kuttner and Eric Holder, and a historian’s warning about the heart of the resistance.
item.dc:creator: James Goodman
item.category: Going Big: FDR's Legacy, Biden's New Deal, and the Struggle to Save Democracy (Book)
Why White Liberals Fail: Race and Southern Politics from FDR to Trump (Book)
Our Unfinished March: The Violent Past and Imperiled Future of the Vote -- A History, A Crisis, A Plan (Book)

item.title: Book Review: “We All Want Impossible Things,” by Catherine Newman
item.description: In her novel “We All Want Impossible Things,” Catherine Newman achieves the near-impossible: a story about death, with humor.
item.dc:creator: Julie Klam
item.category: We All Want Impossible Things: A Novel (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Shanda,’ by Letty Cottin Pogrebin; ‘A Girlhood,’ by Carolyn Hays; ‘The Family Outing,’ by Jessi Hempel
item.description: From lost children to sexual and gender identity, moral crises abound.
item.dc:creator: Jake Nevins
item.category: Shanda: A Memoir of Shame and Secrecy (Book)
A Girlhood: Letter to My Transgender Daughter (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘It’s Not TV,’ by Felix Gillette and John Koblin
item.description: A new history of the entertainment company traces its origins in a culture of male license, misogyny — and violence.
item.dc:creator: Sam Adler-Bell

item.title: Book Review: ‘Magic To Do,' by Elysa Gardner
item.description: Elysa Gardner’s “Magic to Do” goes backstage at Bob Fosse and Stephen Schwartz’s 1972 musical about a lost prince.
item.dc:creator: Marshall Heyman

item.title: Book Review: ‘Cheap Land Colorado,’ by Ted Conover
item.description: For his new book, the journalist Ted Conover joined a community of off-gridders in a desolate corner of the West, capturing lives full of anguish and contradiction.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Cheap Land Colorado: Off-Gridders at America's Edge (Book)

item.title: Newly Published, From Egotistical Artists to Corporate Control
item.description: A selection of recently published books.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Vigilance,’ by Andrew K. Diemer
item.description: Andrew Diemer’s “Vigilance” gives a freedom fighter his due.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Clinton
item.category: Vigilance: The Life of William Still, Father of the Underground Railroad (Book)
item.media:credit: Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, Temple University

item.title: Book Review: ‘Dr. No,’ by Percival Everett
item.description: “Dr. No,” which borrows its name from an early James Bond story, features a math professor who’s recruited by a supervillain.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Book Review: ‘Case Study,’ by Graeme Macrae Burnet
item.description: “Case Study,” by Graeme Macrae Burnet, is a novel of found documents detailing troubled lives and shifting identities.
item.dc:creator: Christian Lorentzen
item.media:credit: Sam Mellish/In Pictures via Getty Images
item.media:description: Primrose Hill, London, where the novel “Case Study” is set.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Requiem for the Massacre,’ by RJ Young
item.description: RJ Young’s “Requiem for the Massacre” is more coming-of-age story than reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Martha Southgate
item.category: Requiem for the Massacre: A Black History on the Conflict, Hope, and Fallout of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre (Book)
item.media:credit: Department of Special Collections, McFarlin Library, The University of Tulsa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A group of Black men are marched down Tulsa’s Main Street on June 1, 1921.

item.title: Review: ‘The Island of Extraordinary Captives,’ by Simon Parkin
item.description: In Simon Parkin’s riveting account, a shameful chapter in British history is also a testament to creativity and hope.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Nicolson
item.media:description: A group of refugees, including future Hutchinson inmate Peter Fleischmann, shortly after disembarking the Kindertransport ferry, 1938.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Saha,’ by Cho Nam-Joo
item.description: In her new novel, “Saha,” Cho Nam-Joo follows a group of outcasts to examine the strict enforcement of social hierarchies.
item.dc:creator: Lincoln Michel

item.title: Book Review: ‘Trespasses,’ by Louise Kennedy
item.description: Louise Kennedy’s debut novel, “Trespasses,” considers the relationship of a Catholic woman and a Protestant man.
item.dc:creator: J. Courtney Sullivan

item.title: Essay: ‘Toad,’ by Katherine Dunn
item.description: The posthumous publication of a new novel, six years after Dunn’s death, is a chance to celebrate the bawdy originality of the author of the cult hit “Geek Love.”
item.dc:creator: Adrienne Raphel

item.title: Book Review: “Before You Knew My Name,” by Jacqueline Bublitz
item.description: Jacqueline Bublitz’s debut, “Before You Knew My Name,” follows the parallel tracks of two women in New York City — one vital and vibrant, the other not so much.
item.dc:creator: Flynn Berry

item.title: Book Review: ‘Mr. B,’ by Jennifer Homans
item.description: “Mr. B,” by Jennifer Homans, explores the life of the Russian-born choreographer, as well as the beauty and pains of his art.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.media:description: The choreographer George Balanchine backstage with one of his dancers in 1972.

item.title: Teaching Children About Climate Change
item.description: Two new picture books and a novel for young readers place children at the center of environmental calamity.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: The Coquies Still Sing: A Story of Home, Hope, and Rebuilding (Book)
Dear Wild Child: You Carry Your Home Inside You (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Surrender,’ by Bono
item.description: In his new book, “Surrender,” the singer remembers hanging out with everyone from the Edge to Bill Gates.
item.dc:creator: Alan Light
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bono the memoirist wrestles with “the pseudo-religious part of being a rock star, how we put the messy in messianic.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘White Horse,’ by Erika T. Wurth
item.description: In Erika T. Wurth’s new horror novel, “White Horse,” a woman searches for the truth about her vanished mother, an investigation that involves confronting literal and metaphorical ghosts.
item.dc:creator: Laura van den Berg

item.title: Children’s Books About Immigration
item.description: Five new picture books explore the meaning of home.
item.dc:creator: Nalini Jones

item.title: Book Review: ‘Foster,’ by Claire Keegan
item.description: Claire Keegan’s new novella sends a poor child into a childless home in southeast Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Alex Gilvarry
